arm_group.description: Patients treated with conventional primary angioplasty

brief_summary.textblock:
The Physiologic Assessment of Thrombus Aspiration in ST-segment Elevation Myocardial
      Infarction (PATA-STEMI) trial is a single center, prospective, randomized trial with a
      planned inclusion of 128 patients with the first ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction
      (STEMI). Patients are, before coronary angiography,  randomly assigned to thrombus
      aspiration using 6 or 7 French Eliminate aspiration catheter (Terumo Medical Supply, Japan)
      or to conventional primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The primary endpoint is
      index of microcirculatory resistance (IMR), measured in infarct-related artery, in thrombus
      aspiration compared to conventional PCI group.

clinical_study.brief_title: Physiologic Assessment of Thrombus Aspiration in Acute ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction Patients

detailed_description.textblock:
Background and Objective Routine thrombus aspiration is superior to conventional primary PCI
      in terms of improved myocardial perfusion in STEMI patients. However, myocardial perfusion
      after thrombus aspiration has not been evaluated by a quantitative, invasive method.
      Investigators intend to determine whether thrombus aspiration of the infarct-related artery
      increases myocardial perfusion, as measured by IMR, compared to conventional primary PCI.

      Study design PATA-STEMI is a single center, prospective, randomized trial with a planned
      inclusion of 128 patients with the first STEMI. Patients are randomly assigned, before
      coronary angiography, to thrombus aspiration using the 6 or 7 French Eliminate aspiration
      catheter (Terumo Medical Supply, Japan) or to conventional primary PCI. The IMR will be
      determined in infarct-related artery and non-infarct-related arteries without critical
      stenosis to measure microcirculatory resistance. The primary endpoint is defined as IMR in
      infarct-related artery in thrombus aspiration compared to conventional PCI group. Secondary
      end points are myocardial perfusion grade and resolution of ST-segment elevation, infarct
      size and left ventricle remodeling, as  assessed by echocardiographic indices. Transthoracic
      echocardiography will be conducted within 24 hours and at 4 months after the primary PCI.

      Implications: If manual thrombus aspiration reduces microcirculatory resistance, indicating
      improved myocardial perfusion, as compared to conventional PCI, it might become the
      preferred strategy in patients with STEMI.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  All consecutive patients with STEMI

          -  chest pain onset ≤12h, or >12 h with persistent ST-segment elevation

          -  hemodynamically stable patients

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  patients without diagnosis of STEMI (pericarditis, for example)

          -  no written informed consent obtained

          -  prior Q or non-Q MI

          -  prior resuscitation

          -  prior thrombolysis

          -  prior surgical myocardial revascularisation

          -  life expectancy <6 months

          -  periprocedural death

clinical_study.official_title: The Randomized Physiologic Assessment of Thrombus Aspiration in Patients With Acute ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction Trial

authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

primary_outcome.description: IMR will be measured after final balloon inflation or stent implantation, an expected average of 45 minutes after sheath insertion
primary_outcome.measure: IMR (mmHg seconds) in thrombus aspiration compared to conventional PCI group
primary_outcome.time_frame: At the end of the primary PCI , an expected average of 45 minutes after sheath insertion

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: ST-segment resolution ≥70% at 60 minutes after guiding catheter removal
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at 60 minutes after guiding catheter removal

secondary_outcome.description: myocardial blush grade will be assessed after IMR measurements, following the final balloon inflation or stent implantation, an expected average of 55 minutes after sheath insertion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at final angiogram, an expected average of 55 minutes after sheath insertion

secondary_outcome.description: infarct size will be determined based on peak enzyme release (Troponin, CK-MB) during in-hospital stay, an expected average of 5 days
secondary_outcome.measure: infarct size assessed by peak enzyme release (Troponin, creatine kinase MB (CK-MB))
secondary_outcome.time_frame: in hospital course after primary PCI, an expected average of 5 days

secondary_outcome.description: left ventricle remodeling will be assessed on Echocardiography within 24 hours and at 4 months after primary PCI
secondary_outcome.measure: indices of left ventricle remodeling on Echocardiography
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 24 hours and at 4 months after primary PCI

secondary_outcome.description: infarct size will be determined by SPECT within 7-14 days and at 4 months after primary PCI
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within 7-14 days and at 4 months after primary PCI

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
